Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 42, 507, 58]]<|/det|>
## 2  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 126, 89]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 640, 529]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{ C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{ kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{ kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{ kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{- 1} \text{ mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{ J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{ N m}^{2} \text{ kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{ F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{ m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{ J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{ W m}^{- 2} \text{ K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 581]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 597, 322, 615]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 650, 250, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 682, 151, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 723, 339, 740]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 761, 207, 778]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 793, 228, 809]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 238, 845]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel

\[g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\]

\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 161, 625, 181]]<|/det|>
\[e = 1.60\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 191, 630, 212]]<|/det|>
\[1\mathrm{u} = 1.66\times 10^{-27}\mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 222, 630, 243]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{-27}\mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 253, 630, 273]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 284, 648, 305]]<|/det|>
\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 316, 630, 336]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 346, 640, 366]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 377, 688, 398]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{Nm}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]

\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

\[\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{Wm}^{-2}\mathrm{K}^{-4}\]

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 648, 551, 667]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 677, 544, 696]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 707, 556, 744]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 756, 551, 776]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 787, 606, 808]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 817, 613, 852]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A spherical balloon is filled with a fixed mass of gas. A small block is connected by a string to the balloon, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 112, 688, 284]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 299, 591, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
The block is held on the ground by an external force so that the string is vertical. The density of the air surrounding the balloon is \(1.2 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). The upthrust acting on the balloon is \(0.071 \text{N}\). The upthrust acting on the string and block is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 393, 146, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 393, 712, 411]]<|/det|>
By using Archimedes' principle, calculate the radius \(r\) of the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 561, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<form>r = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 593, 146, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 592, 638, 611]]<|/det|>
The total weight of the balloon, string and block is 0.053 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 624, 920, 656]]<|/det|>
The external force holding the block on the ground is removed so that the released block is lifted vertically upwards by the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 732, 688]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration of the block immediately after it is released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The balloon continues to lift the block. The string breaks as the block is moving vertically upwards with a speed of \(1.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\). After the string breaks, the detached block briefly continues moving upwards before falling vertically downwards to the ground. The block hits the ground with a speed of \(3.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 620, 166]]<|/det|>
Assume that the air resistance on the block is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 181, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
By considering the motion of the block after the string breaks, calculate the height of the block above the ground when the string breaks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 414, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<form>height = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 446, 180, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 446, 796, 463]]<|/det|>
The string breaks at time \(t = 0\) and the block hits the ground at time \(t = T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 922, 509]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the velocity \(\nu\) of the block with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 917, 540]]<|/det|>
Numerical values of \(t\) are not required. Assume that \(\nu\) is positive in the upward direction.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 551, 714, 838]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 857, 534, 875]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 873, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 904, 920, 921]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 621, 91]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the centre of gravity of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
A uniform beam AB is attached by a frictionless hinge to a vertical wall at end A. The beam is held so that it is horizontal by a metal wire CD, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 205, 787, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 438, 591, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
The beam is of length \(0.96 \text{m}\) and weight \(23 \text{N}.\) A block of weight \(W\) rests on the beam at a distance of \(0.20 \text{m}\) from end B. The wire is attached to the beam at point D which is a distance of \(0.40 \text{m}\) from end B. The wire exerts a force on the beam of \(45 \text{N}\) at an angle of \(37^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The beam is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 547, 181, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 839, 565]]<|/det|>
Calculate the vertical component of the force exerted by the wire on the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 637, 920, 656]]<|/det|>
<form>vertical component of the force = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 181, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 724, 688]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about A, calculate the weight \(W\) of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 886, 920, 905]]<|/det|>
<form>W = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 584, 88]]<|/det|>
The hinge exerts a force on the beam at end A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 594, 119]]<|/det|>
Calculate the horizontal component of this force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 195, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
<form>horizontal component of force = ............................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 227, 178, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 648, 244]]<|/det|>
The block is now placed closer to point D on the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 257, 920, 289]]<|/det|>
State whether this change will increase, decrease or have no effect on the tension in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 304, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 335, 181, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 920, 382]]<|/det|>
The stress in the wire is \(5.3 \times 10^{7} \text{Pa}\). The wire is now replaced by a second wire that has a radius which is three times greater than that of the original wire. The tension in the wire is unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 520, 413]]<|/det|>
Calculate the stress in the second wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 551, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
<form>stress = .................................................... $Pa$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 581, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A horizontal spring is fixed at one end. A block is pushed against the other end of the spring so that the spring is compressed, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 112, 771, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 234, 532, 253]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
The block is released and accelerates along a horizontal frictionless surface as the spring returns to its original length. The block leaves the end of the spring with a speed of \(2.3 \text{m s}^{-1}\), as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 323, 771, 438]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 453, 532, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 784, 504]]<|/det|>
The block has a mass of \(250\mathrm{g}\) and the spring has a spring constant of \(420\mathrm{Nm}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
Assume that the spring always obeys Hooke's law and that all the elastic potential energy of the spring is transferred to the kinetic energy of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 144, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 675, 580]]<|/det|>
Calculate the kinetic energy of the block as it leaves the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 700, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 732, 146, 751]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 826, 751]]<|/det|>
Calculate the compression of the spring immediately before the block is released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 887, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
<form>compression = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
After leaving the spring, the block moves along the surface until it hits a barrier at a speed of \(2.3 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The block then rebounds at a speed of \(1.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and moves back along its original path. The block is in contact with the barrier for a time of \(0.086 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 243, 150]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 181, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 163, 665, 183]]<|/det|>
the change in momentum of the block during the collision

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<form>change in momentum = .................................................... $N$ s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 319, 752, 338]]<|/det|>
the average resultant force exerted on the block during the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 429, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<form>average resultant force = .................................................... $N$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 429, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 148, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The maximum compression \(x\) of the spring is now varied in order to vary the kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the block as it leaves the spring. Assume that all the elastic potential energy in the spring is always transferred to the kinetic energy of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 522, 663, 542]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with \(x\) of \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 549, 640, 715]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 732, 534, 751]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 747, 920, 765]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 777, 920, 796]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two progressive sound waves meet to form a stationary wave. The two waves have the same amplitude, wavelength, frequency and speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
State the other condition that must be fulfilled by the two waves in order for them to produce the stationary wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
A stationary wave is formed on a string that is stretched between two fixed points A and B. Fig. 5.1 shows the string at time \(t = 0\) when each point is at its maximum displacement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 234, 824, 317]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 329, 532, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 710, 380]]<|/det|>
Distance AB is \(0.80 \text{m}\). The period of the stationary wave is \(0.016 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 393, 181, 412]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 393, 722, 412]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, sketch a solid line to show the position of the string:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 424, 524, 443]]<|/det|>
● at time \(t = 0.004 \text{s}\) (label this line P)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 454, 532, 473]]<|/det|>
● at time \(t = 0.024 \text{s}\) (label this line Q).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 470, 920, 489]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 501, 181, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 501, 692, 520]]<|/det|>
Determine the speed of a progressive wave along the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A beam of vertically polarised light of intensity \(I_0\) is incident normally on a polarising filter that has its transmission axis at \(30^{\circ}\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 114, 875, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 316, 532, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
The transmitted light from the first polarising filter has intensity \(I_{1}\). This light is then incident normally on a second polarising filter that has its transmission axis at \(90^{\circ}\) to the vertical. The transmitted light from the second filter has intensity \(I_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 243, 426]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 181, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 435, 291, 470]]<|/det|>
the ratio \(\frac{I_1}{I_0}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 585, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{I_1}{I_0} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 625, 180, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 621, 293, 655]]<|/det|>
the ratio \(\frac{I_2}{I_0}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 774, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{I_2}{I_0} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 812, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 443, 90]]<|/det|>
Define electric potential difference.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 720, 183]]<|/det|>
A battery is connected to two resistors X and Y, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 191, 668, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 318, 533, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 349, 737, 368]]<|/det|>
The resistance of resistor X is greater than the resistance of resistor Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 616, 399]]<|/det|>
State and explain which resistor dissipates more power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 536, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 566, 146, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 566, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 9.0V and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to two resistors P and Q, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 606, 630, 845]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 861, 533, 880]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A total charge of \(650 \text{C}\) moves through resistor P in a time interval of \(540 \text{s}\). During this time resistor P dissipates \(4800 \text{J}\) of energy. The current in resistor Q is \(4.5 \text{A}\). Assume that the e.m.f. of the battery remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 243, 151]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 183, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 390, 182]]<|/det|>
the current in resistor P

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 318, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>current = .................................................... A [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 350, 529, 368]]<|/det|>
the potential difference across resistor P

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<form>potential difference = ................................................. V [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 536, 180, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 536, 507, 554]]<|/det|>
the internal resistance \(r\) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 691, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
<form>r = ...................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 720, 920, 738]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]
